abstract: Lots of opportunities, if you actively ask for them
tenure: I worked at Bharti Airtel full-time
pro: (1) Fast paced environment. Lots of opportunities to learn. Very skilled colleagues (at least in the finance vertical).    (2) Plenty of opportunities to manage serious projects with real responsibilities, if you satisfy management of your ability to handle them. Once you are accepted as a "contributing member" of the team, you will be offered far more respect, more serious projects and more autonomy.    (3) Significant opportunities to work and learn from cross functional teams. If you have a unique skill set, quite common to work with (and learn from) different teams.    (4) New challenges to work on every week: no lack of stimuli.    (5) Excellent team ethic across the board (see (2)).    (6) Frequent opportunities to socialize outside of work.
con: (1) Not uncommon to spend 12+ hours at the office. Employees are not required to, but is very common, even on company mandated half-days. Interns who have been entrusted responsibilities are expected to, if they want to continue being taken seriously. Fortunately, the exciting fast paced nature of work and excellent team members often make this more than tolerable.    (2) Poor processes are in place to accommodate interns/new employees not from the Young Leaders Program.     (3) Employees/Managers are often swamped; interns, therefore are expected to take initiative and repeatedly ask to be given a chance to contribute (see (2)) . If you don't nudge repeatedly, you will spend the entire period of internship doing nothing. It will still be a while before you are entrusted with any real tasks. You just have to trudge through this part. Unfortunately, in case of summer internships, your time will be over before you get to any real tasks.

abstract: So much politics that it can form a political party.
tenure: I worked at Bharti Airtel full-time for more than 3 years
pro: Bharti Airtel has a good brand image and also the market leaders in the telecom domain. That's the only pro i can think of.
con: All employees are pretty much in the mid-senior age category and are probably going to stay till retirement.  The irony is although the company projects itself as a technical leader in the industry that bring innovation, the most technical tool that the employees use within he organization is limited to MS excel.     Horrible company to start your career with. Young college graduates are lured in with gimmicks and fancy words such as 'Young Leaders' and 'Young Technical Leaders', but in reality the work is menial, dull, repetitive. Not to mention, one can get a call/email even at 3:00 AM at night and the management expects you to answer it/reply by 7:00 A. Else, embrace yourself to handle an escalated complaint.     Politics runs in the veins of every employee. Promotions are based on personal relationship with managers, HR and employee caliber and potential is the last thing that is taken into consideration.

abstract: Bharti Airtel is a company you can retire with
tenure: I worked at Bharti Airtel
pro: The brand and the general quality of the senior management. The take home in terms of experience and knowledge is very good provided a sincere effort is attempted from the side of the employee. The sharing of knowledge is absolutely completed. There are adequate number of leaves and the five day working day is comparable to any MNC. There are platforms for employee get togethers and adequate training on relevant matters as required for the execution of your job profile. The employee engagement programes are also good.  The rating system on the performance is generally fair and transparent and the ESOP scheme also
con: The pressure to perform is very severe from the top level and it gets cascaded to all the levels. Even though there is not much politics the dependence on the individual rating officer sometimes help earning average ratings which ultimately affect the compensation. The HR team is not upto the mark in terms of employee benefits and not easily disclose people policies. the onus is on the employee to find out the policies and how it will benefit him. the cost control measures sometimes goes to such levels that various inhouse parties and get togethers are not approved. the level of hierarchy is too complicated
